title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 § 2188.5 - Threshold Eligibility Requirements for LIHTC Allocation
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 § 2188.5 - Threshold Eligibility Requirements for LIHTC Allocation

State Regulations

At each stage of processing, applications will be subject
to a threshold eligibility review, which will include, but not necessarily be
limited to, whether the project meets the following minimum
requirements: (a) The applicant is
willing to enter into a regulatory agreement with HFA requiring the project to
conform to the income, occupancy and rent restrictions of IRC section
42. (b) The applicant is willing to
enter into a regulatory agreement with HFA for extended Low-Income use of the
project with a minimum extended use period, ending no earlier than 30 years
after the project is placed in service, or a later date which the agency may
establish, that is in conformance with the requirements of IRC section 42, includes an agreement to waive the right to request a qualified contract and
provides that the extended use period will not be subject to early termination
pursuant to the qualified contract provisions of the Code. The regulatory
agreement shall include provisions requiring that project reserves must be used
to maintain the property, benefit its residents, and remain with the project
throughout the extended use period except as otherwise consented to by the
agency. The regulatory agreement shall provide that if a Qualified

Nonprofit Organization (as defined in IRC section 42(h)(5)(C)) is involved in
the project (as described in IRC section 42(h)(5)(B)) or if the tenants of the
project otherwise hold a right of first refusal pursuant to IRC section
42(i)(7) then a right of first refusal agreement ("ROFR Agreement") must be
entered into in such form as may be approved by the agency. The agency recognizes that no Federal income tax benefit
shall fail to be allowable to the taxpayer with respect to any qualified

Low-Income building merely by reason of a right of first refusal ("ROFR") held
by the tenants (in cooperative form or otherwise) or resident management
corporation of such building or by a Qualified Nonprofit Organization (as
defined in IRC section 42(h)(5)(C)) pursuant to IRC section 42(i)(7). Any
project in which a Qualified Nonprofit Organization is involved (within the
meaning of IRC section 42(h)(5)(B)) shall enter into a ROFR Agreement which
complies with the terms of IRC section 42(i)(7). Projects in which a Qualified Nonprofit Organization (as
set forth in IRC section 42(i)(7)) intends to exercise its ROFR pursuant to IRC
section 42(i)(7), as amended from time to time, must enter into a ROFR
Agreement which meets the requirements of this section. The ROFR Agreement must
state that the parties thereto agree that the right of first refusal
contemplated in such ROFR Agreement and allowed for under IRC section 42(i)(7)
does not require nor will it be conditioned upon a bona fide third-party offer, as otherwise may be required under law, including statutory, court-interpreted, or common law. The ROFR Agreement must state that the intent of the parties is
that the seller is a willing seller under the terms of the ROFR Agreement. The
ROFR Agreement must state the ROFR may be exercised at any time after the close
of the Compliance Period. Once exercised, the Qualified Nonprofit Organization
shall have at least 12 months to close on the purchase of the project or the
interests of the non-managing members or partners in the project's ownership
entity or entities. The ROFR Agreement shall state that, with the written
consent of the agency, the Qualified Nonprofit Organization may assign the ROFR
Agreement to another Qualified Nonprofit Organization which may include a
related party. Consent to such sale by the other members, partners, or other
entities holding an ownership interest in the project shall not be unreasonably
withheld, conditioned, or delayed, nor withheld for a non-material breach of
the project's organizational documents. The ROFR Agreement must state there are
no other conditions to the exercise of the ROFR except as explicitly identified
in the ROFR Agreement. The purchase price to exercise the ROFR set forth in the
ROFR Agreement shall be calculated in accord with the minimum purchase price
pursuant to IRC section 42(i)(7)(B). Any additional amounts added to such
purchase price will be subject to the agency's consent and approval prior to
the exercise of the ROFR. The agency's review in connection with issuance of
such consent to any such additional amounts shall be for the purpose of
maintaining the long-term financial stability and affordability of the project. The ROFR Agreement shall state that in the event that IRC section 42(i)(7) is
amended to provide for an option to purchase, as opposed to or in addition to a
right of first refusal, the Qualified Nonprofit Organization may elect to
exercise such option in the manner allowed under the Code, notwithstanding
anything set forth in the ROFR Agreement. The ROFR Agreement shall require the
agency's consent for any material amendments thereto or assignments
thereof. Projects in which a Qualified Nonprofit Organization (as
defined in IRC section 42(h)(5)(C)) intends to exercise its ROFR based on IRC
section 42(i)(7), as may be amended from time to time, must submit a letter of
intent from a tax credit investor in which the investor agrees and certifies
that it will enter into a ROFR Agreement, with the approval of the agency, which grants a right of first refusal to the Qualified Nonprofit Organization
to purchase the project and which complies with the provisions of this section. Projects in which a Qualified Nonprofit Organization does not hold an ownership
interest and is not otherwise involved (as described in IRC section
42(h)(5)(B)) but instead tenants in the project (organized in cooperative or
other form) or a partner, member or other entity in the project ownership
structure intends to exercise a ROFR must submit a letter of intent from a tax
credit investor in which the investor agrees and certifies it will enter into a
ROFR Agreement with such entity, which grants a ROFR to such entity to purchase
the project, in such form as may be approved by and consented to by the
agency. (c) The applicant
agrees to comply with all applicable Federal and State fair housing laws and
regulations and not to engage in any illegal discriminatory conduct including
discrimination against section 8 voucher tenants. (d) The project receives an acceptable

Financial Feasibility Review and underwrites in accordance with the applicable
HFA underwriting criteria including meeting any criteria limiting costs, fees
or expenses contained in the QAP and/or any additional agency guidance, which
may include a pertinent term sheet. The Financial Feasibility Review will be
conducted using the standards in the QAP and/or any additional agency guidance, which may include a pertinent Term Sheet. (e) The eligible basis of all the buildings
in a project divided by the number of units in a project, prior to any increase
for buildings in high cost areas under section 42(d)(5)(B), in the applicant's
request for LIHTC and/or in any cost certification to support the allocation of
such LIHTC, does not exceed the per unit eligible basis limit or the eligible
basis has been reduced to the maximum eligible basis permitted by the per unit
eligible basis limit under section
2188.3
(e)(1)(ii) and
(f)(1)
of this Part. This requirement may be
waived by the agency, if the agency determines that it is in the public
interest to recognize a greater amount of eligible basis per unit. (f) The project is of the appropriate type
(new construction, substantial rehabilitation, moderate rehabilitation and/or
acquisition) and design needed to address the housing needs in the area where
project is located. (g) The size of
the units in the proposed project must be appropriate for the type of occupancy
proposed. (h) The applicant has
site control, consistent with the Code, for the project real estate through a
lease, option, purchase contract or deed. (i) At the time of application, the project
applicant has identified all required governmental approvals necessary to
construct and operate the project. At each subsequent stage of processing, the
applicant must secure all required governmental approvals to construct and
operate the project. (j) The
project applicant has successfully developed and operated projects comparable
to the proposed project and/or has, or will obtain, the capacity and experience
to undertake, complete and operate the proposed project. (k) The agency has, prior to the second LIHTC
underwriting, completed a credit and background review of the project
developer, owner and/or manager and their principals with acceptable
results. (l) The project developer, owner and/or manager and their principals does not include anyone who has
participated in a State assisted program or project, with HFA, DHCR or any
other State entity, that has been determined to be out of compliance with
statutes, rules, regulations, policies or agreements and has not been corrected
or otherwise resolved as determined by the supervising agency. The project
developer, owner and/or manager and their principals also does not include
anyone who, in sole judgement of the agency, has initiated or been the decision
maker in requesting a qualified contract under section 42(h)(6)(F) after May
26, 2021. The project developer, owner and/or manager and their principals must
inform the agency in a timely manner of any notice of non-compliance issued at
any time. (m) An independent, third-party appraisal conducted by a New York State licensed appraiser, and
commissioned by the credit enhancement provider is required and subject to HFA
review and approval. The project's acquisition cost as set forth in the
appraisal must be the lesser of the actual acquisition cost or the value
supported by an as-is value and should distinctly separate the value attributed
to the land allowing for a clear assessment of the land's contribution to the
overall cost. The appraisal must be consistent with the analysis of rents and
operating expenses presented in the application. If necessary, an independent
market study may be requested, at HFA's sole discretion. (n) If the project developer, owner and/or
manager and/or their principals have had any prior involvement with HFA, there
are no unresolved LIHTC compliance or other compliance issues. The project
developer, owner and/or manager and their principals must inform HFA in a
timely manner of any notice of non-compliance issued at any time. (o) If the project developer, owner and/or
manager and/or their principals have had any prior involvement with any State
agency financing housing, there are no outstanding defaults or compliance
problems which have not been resolved to the satisfaction of the agency
involved. (p) Projects which
contain both Low-Income and market rate units must comply with the agency's
proportionality and distribution policy unless such compliance is waived by
HFA. (1)

The agency's proportionality and
distribution policy provides that Low-Income Units must be comparable to market
rate units; the Low-Income Units must be acceptably distributed through all
unit types and all floors and/or buildings in the project; and no floor and/or
building should contain an undue concentration of Low-Income Units. (2)

The average quality standard must be the
same for the Low-Income U nits as for the market rate units unless the agency
approves additional or modified amenities which cause the market rate units to
be above the average quality standard of Low-Income Units. (3)

If the market rate units are above the
average quality standard of the Low-Income U nits, the project is subject to
the provisions of Code section 42(d)(3) which reduces eligible basis where
there are disproportionate standards for units and the applicant must advise
the agency, and any cost certification must certify, if the cost on a per
square foot basis for the market rate units is no more than 15 percent more
than the cost for the Low-Income U nits and therefore meets the requirements of
IRC section 42(d)(3)(B)(i)(I) and is, or will be, excluded from basis pursuant
to IRC section 42(d)(3)(B)(i)(II). (q) The project's design and construction
must comply with both HCR's design guidelines and sustainability guidelines, as
appropriate for the type of building proposed as may also be set forth in a
request for proposals and /or other agency guidance, which may include a
pertinent Term Sheet. Rehabilitation projects must take into account, among
other factors, cost effectiveness based on the scope of reconstruction
necessary and the historic nature of the project. All projects must identify
how sustainability requirements will be met and agree to provide, prior to
construction closing, a certification from a responsible green and/or energy
professional that the project will meet such requirements. (r) The project's design and construction
must provide for a percentage of accessible units for persons with mobility and
hearing/vision impairments as defined in HCR's design guidelines, request for
proposals and/or other agency guidance, which may include a pertinent Term

Sheet. (s) All LIHTC-assisted first
floor units in new construction projects without an elevator, all LIHTC
assisted units in new construction projects with an elevator, and as many
LIHTC-assisted units as feasible in adaptive reuse or rehabilitation projects
shall meet Visitability Standards, except when such standards are demonstrated
to be irreconcilable with Federal, State or local statutes, regulations, ordinances or codes. (t) The
applicant will agree to permit HFA to commission a cost audit of all the
project related costs, agree to permit the agency to commission an energy and
green performance audit and include a provision in all contracts with
contractors, design professionals and consultants that permits the agency's
auditors to examine the books and records relevant to the project. (u) The project applicant agrees not to
contract for any services related to the project with any entity on any Federal
or New York State debarment list and include a provision in all contracts
related to the project barring the participation of entities on such
lists. (v) The project applicant, developer, owner, general contractor and/or manager and their principals are in
compliance with all relevant Federal and New York State laws, division and/or
agency policies and requirements, and local laws and regulations, including but
not limited to all fair housing and antidiscrimination requirements and the
prohibition against discriminating against section 8 housing choice voucher
holders, nondiscrimination and marketing policies, guidelines and
requirements. (w) The project shall
address any environmental review standards, as established by the agency, and
which may be set forth in any agency guidance, which may include a pertinent

Term Sheet. (x) The project is
further subject to any additional threshold eligibility review criteria as may
be set forth in other agency guidance, which may include a pertinent Term

Sheet. Notes
